'''Michael Burks''' (July 30, 1957 – May 6, 2012) was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[soul blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. He is best known for his tracks, "I Smell Smoke" and "Hard Come, Easy Go", and variously worked with [[Johnnie Taylor]], [[O. V. Wright]], and Marquise Knox.  He was the son of the bassist, Frederick Burks.<ref name="Dead"/>

The [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Tim Sheridan once noted "... while his vocals are not stellar, he has a rich, gritty quality to his singing that is nicely matched to his guitar playing."<ref name="Make It Rain">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=make-it-rain-r523172/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Make It Rain'' > Overview |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>  Burks was known as 'Iron Man' for his energetic and passion filled performances on stage. He was nominated five times for a [[Blues Music Award]] and, in 2004, ''[[Living Blues]]'' presented him with the Critics' Award for Best Guitarist.<ref name="Post">{{cite news |title=Michael 'Iron Man' Burks Dies at 54|author=Emma Koonse|url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/michael-iron-man-burks-dies-at-54-74514/ |newspaper=[[The Christian Post]] |date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Blues Music Award">{{cite web|url=https://blues.org/#ref=bluesmusicawards_nominees|title=Blues Music Awards Nominees - 2013 - 34th Blues Music Awards|publisher=Blues.org|accessdate=2013-03-20}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Burks was born in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], [[United States]],<ref name="Obit">{{cite news |title=Arkansas bluesman Michael "Iron Man" Burks dies after collapsing at Atlanta airport|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/arkansas-bluesman-michael-iron-man-burks-dies-after-collapsing-at-atlanta-airport/2012/05/07/gIQAyDn37T_story.html |author=Associated Press|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref> and had a musical heritage.  His father played the bass guitar, and performed with [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]], whilst his grandfather had played in a [[delta blues]] style. Burks junior had learned to play the guitar by the age of five, and first played on stage in his cousin's band.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Greg Prato |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/michael-burks-mn0000391241/biography |title=Michael Burks | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> In the early 1970s, Burks moved with his family to [[Camden, Arkansas]].  It was there that Burks and his father built a 300 seater [[juke joint]] named the Bradley Ferry Country Club, where Burks duly led the [[house band]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Obit"/> 

After the club closed in the mid 1980s, Burks was employed as a mechanic at [[Lockheed Martin]].  He continued to play at local clubs and [[music festival]]s, until 1997, when he recorded and produced his debut album, ''From the Inside Out''. The magazine, ''Blues Access'', stated it was "the most impressive indie in recent memory", and ''[[Living Blues]]'' described it as one of "the best debut discs of the year."<ref name="AMG"/> In 2001, [[Alligator Records]] signed Burks to a [[recording contract]], and he released ''Make It Rain'' with them the same year. ''Make It Rain'' was produced by Jim Gaines and [[Bruce Iglauer]]. ''I Smell Smoke'' followed in 2003, and five years later Burks issued what turned out to be the final album in his lifetime, ''Iron Man'', named for his long held [[nickname]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2012.html|title= The Dead Rock Stars Club - January to June 2012|publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Obit"/>

Burks was a regular performer at the [[King Biscuit Blues Festival]].<ref name="Obit"/>  He also appeared at [[Memphis in May]] in 2004 and 2009. Burks had completed recording his fifth album, which was due to be released in July 2012.<ref name="Post"/>

On May 6, 2012, upon returning from a tour of Europe, Burks collapsed at [[Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport]].  He was shortly after pronounced dead from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]], at a hospital in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], aged 54.<ref name="Dead"/><ref name="Obit"/>

In 2013, Burks took the [[Blues Music Award]] "Contemporary Blues Album of the Year" and "Album of the Year" categories with his posthumous release, ''Show Of Strength''.<ref name="Blues Music Award"/>
